titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Gardner Stewart Williams Papers, 1900-1945
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Helmi Raaska, January 1983

did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan based hydraulic engineer known for his multiple arch dams, hydroelectric plants, and for developing the Hazen-Williams hydraulic tables, designed and consulted on numerous water power and dam projects. Papers include biographical files, material relating to construction of dams and power plants on the Huron River and elsewhere, and papers relating to Michigan Engineering Society.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from the Ann Arbor engineering firm, Ayres, Lewis, Norris and May in December 1981 (donor no. 5642). In 2011, an additional volume was donated by Bill Wheeler (donor no. 10511).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Gardner Stewart Williams Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Gardner Stewart Williams was born in Saginaw, Michigan, in 1866. He was graduated from Saginaw City High School in 1884, and received a degree in civil engineering from the University of Michigan in 1889.

Williams became a nationally recognized authority in hydraulic engineering, and was known for his multiple arch dams, hydroelectric plants, and for developing the Hazen-Williams hydraulic tables. He was employed as an engineer on water works construction at Bismarck, North Dakota, and at Greenville and Owosso, Michigan. From 1890 to 1893 he was a draftsman and engineer with the Russell Wheel and Foundry Company of Detroit, and from 1893 to 1898 was civil engineer to the Detroit Board of Water Commissioners. It was while he was in Detroit that he developed the valuable Hazen-Williams Tables, which calculate the headloss in pipes.

From 1898 to 1904 Williams was professor of experimental hydraulics and engineer in charge of the hydraulic laboratory at Cornell University, and from 1904 to 1911 was professor of civil, hydraulic and sanitary engineering at the University of Michigan.

Williams had been a consulting engineering since 1895, and was in increasing demand as a consultant. In 1911 he resigned from the University and devoted full time to his consulting practice. He opened his first office with Robert Norris, a former student, as a subordinate. From 1911 to 1931 Williams had a wide range of engineering interests, and his company had offices in Ann Arbor and Chicago. In addition to being an engineering consultant, Williams acted as an agent for his hydroelectric clients and purchased the flowage rights along various rivers. He also became known as an expert witness and testified in court cases throughout the United States about the causes of hydraulic failures. In 1923 his consulting firm formed a partnership known as Ayres, Lewis, Norris and May. Williams, however, preferred to remain as an independent consultant.

Among his many accomplishments, Williams designed the single arch Cheeseborough Dam in Ithaca, New York, in 1906; the multiple arch dam at Sturgis, Michigan, which was built in 1910; and the water power plant at Sault Ste. Marie. In 1930 he designed the Magnitogorsky Dam on the Ural River in Siberia, Russia.

As consultant for the Detroit Edison Company, Williams prepared a proposal for the development of the Huron River water powers. By 1910 Detroit Edison, with Williams acting as their agent, had acquired most of the prospective flowage rights necessary for the project. The Huron River development was not completed as planned, but six dams were built: Barton in 1912, Argo in 1913, Geddes in 1916, Superior in 1919, French Landing in 1925, and Rawsonville (owned by Henry Ford) in 1927.

arrangement.p: The Gardner Stewart William papers, 1900-1931 are arranged in five series:

list.item:
Power Plants and Dams
Huron River Power Plants and Dams
Other Power Plants and Dams

scopecontent.p: The papers of Gardner Williams, 1900-1931, include biographical material; papers relating to the history of Michigan Engineering Society; project files detailing construction of Huron River power plants and dams at Argo, Barton, Geddes, Superior, and French Landing; other Michigan project files for dams and plants in Sault Ste. Marie and elsewhere; Detroit Edison consultation materials; engineering reports by, or including comments of, Williams; and photographs.

The Williams papers came from the offices of Ayres, Lewis, Norris and May, Ann Arbor engineering firm. Obviously a fragment, they cover only the period of 1900 to 1931, with photographs spanning the dates 1900 to 1945.

The collection begins with a folder of biographical material and a folder regarding the history of the Michigan Engineering Society. Except for these, the collection divides into four series: Power Plants and Dams, the Detroit Edison Company, Engineering Reports, and Photographs.

did.unittitle: History of the Michigan Engineering Society
Huron River Power Plants and Dams

scopecontent.p: Power Plants and Dams relates to dams and plants along the Huron River as well as to other water development projects in Michigan. These files consist of business correspondence on matters of land purchases and flowage rights, blueprints and drawings, contract documents and specifications, computations, and tests. Some of the Huron River projects documented include Argo, Barton, Geddes, Superior and French Landing. Some of the other files concern projects in Allegan, Alpena, Hart, Lowell, Rawsonville, and Sault Ste. Marie. Included with this subgroup are files relating to tests and experiments with draft tubes and the design of multiple arch dams.

did.unittitle: Maps of the Huron River Valley from Surveys made in 1908, 1909
Preliminary Report of the Proposed Development of the Huron River Water Powers 1912
Cost New and Cost Less Depreciation of Huron River Power Plants 1915
Head Race, Tail Race, and Canal 1912-1914

scopecontent.p: The Detroit Edison series contains correspondence relating to land purchases, reports, and a company history.
The Reports series consists of reports either written by Williams or commented upon by him. Most concern Michigan projects and relate to the development of water power.

did.unittitle: Experimental Investigation Upon the Measurement of Discharge of Turbine Wheels made for the Michigan Lake Superior Power Company 1900
The Applicability of the Francis Formula for the Flow of Water over Weirs to the conditions existing at the Holyoke Testing Flume 1901
The Flow of Water over Weirs 1905
Reports on the Valuation and Extension of the Ann Arbor Water Works 1912
Water Power of the Tittabawassee River 1913
The Electrical Department of the Sanitary District of Chicago, Account Classification 1916
Preliminary and Supplementary Report to the Great Northern Power Company Upon the Development of Additional Power 1919
A Brief Upon the Potential Water Power of the Great Lakes - St. Lawrence Waterway 1921
Special Report on the Proposed Water Power Development on the St. Louis River near Scanlon, Minnesota 1921
Report on the Storage Requirements at the Thomson Plant of the Great Northern Power Company 1922
A Study of the Flow of Water over Weirs 1924
Report on the Valuation of the Property of the Beaverton Power Company 1924
A Municipal Hydroelectric Plant-Replacing Steam by Water Power in the City of Sturgis, Michigan undated

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series (1900-1945) includes albums and other photographs of dam construction and other construction projects in Michigan and elsewhere, especially the Argo, Barton, Geddes, and Superior dams on the Huron River, and photographs of rivers and riverside scenes as they existed before dam construction began.

scopecontent.p: Gardner Williams surveyed the Huron River in Washtenaw and Wayne Counties between 1905 and 1909 for the Eastern Michigan Edison Company. The Huron River Survey Maps series contains original maps and some copies from these surveys. Each map is numbered, but does not include a distinctive title. For this finding aid we have provided titles based on a landmark found on each map. The Bentley Historical Library also holds a photographically reproduced set of these maps at a smaller size (MH 4 W319 1909 W723). The original maps in this collection include later additions and changes not found on the photographic copies. Scanned images of the maps are linked from the descriptions below.

odd.p: (this map is available only as copies in folder 7)
(this map is only available as a photographic reproduction, see MH 4 W319 1909 W723)

scopecontent.p: A digital composite map of the Huron River Watershed was created from Bentley Historical Library scans of maps from the Gardner S. Williams collection. The composite image created by Huron River Watershed Council staff.
